問題：

“Given the limited funding available for the building and repair of roads and bridges, the government should not spend any money this year on fixing the bridge that crosses the Styx River. This bridge is located near a city with a weakening economy, so it is not as important as other bridges; moreover, the city population is small and thus unlikely to contribute a significant enough tax revenue to justify the effort of fixing the bridge.”
To what extent do you agree or disagree with this statement, and why?

答：

Owing to the limited availability of resources, the allocation of government funding is usually controversial as the interests of some in the society are often neglected. The authority is responsible for ensuring that people can meet their basic needs such as food, water and shelter, the economic status of a city should not be the governing factor of whether fundings should be spent on improving infrastructure such as roads or bridges. Hence, I disagree with the above statement to a large extent.

The bridge crossing Styx River should not be considered less important to other bridges located near wealthier cities as it is an essential facility to the community, the members of the city shall not be deprived of the rights to using infrastructure only because of its weaker economic status as compared to the others. Even though resources are limited, a more holistic approach should be adopted to assess whether the bridge is of higher priority, it is important to ensure that there will be no adverse impact on the society. For instance, while people will keep on using the bridge on a regular basis, it is critical to ensure that there will be no safety issues arising even if the bridge remains unfixed.

My answer is as below:

To a large extent I concur with the statement, there are some justifications supporting my stance in terms of economic revenue and social aspect.

Regarding the city current economic situation, the city is suffering from inadequate funding and resources for repairing buildings, public facilities. Thus, we have to consider the economic revenue brought by the repairing work and achieve profit maximization as a result. Repairing the bridge cannot bring substantial revenue to our city since few people choose to use the bridge for the purpose of business trade. More important, people in the city are mostly unprivileged and its economy is declining now, it is believed the project cannot achieve profit maximization as there are still other better options for us to allocate and put our funding in the other choices.

With respect to social aspect, our main purpose for repairing project is to ameliorate people’s quality of life. In contrast, the population amount of the city is not large enough and hence the advantages of fixing the bridge will not be very significant for people. In fact, we should consider the benefit to the whole city and based on this principle, it is not economic to fix the bridge for small amount of people. As long as we intend to repair the public facility to facilitate people’s transport convenience, we should consider facilities which are mainly relied on by the majority in the city. In this way, we can make sure that our funding can be utilized to improve people’s quality of life.

All in all, those two justifications explain why we should not repair that bridge from economic and social aspect respectively. It is hoped that our funding can be used in projects which are conducive for improving people city’s competitiveness and people’s transport convenience.
